member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.ClusterMetadata.ShippingOption
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ShippingOption.
The shipping speed for each node in this cluster. This speed doesn't dictate how soon you'll get each device, rather it represents how quickly each device moves to its destination while in transit. Regional shipping speeds are as follows:
In Australia, you have access to express shipping. Typically, devices shipped express are delivered in about a day.
In the European Union (EU), you have access to express shipping. Typically, Snow devices shipped express are delivered in about a day. In addition, most countries in the EU have access to standard shipping, which typically takes less than a week, one way.
In India, Snow devices are delivered in one to seven days.
In the US, you have access to one-day shipping and two-day shipping.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.ClusterMetadata.SnowballType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SnowballType.
The type of AWS Snow device to use for this cluster.
For cluster jobs, AWS Snow Family currently supports only the EDGE device type.

The tax documents required in your AWS Region.

member.summary: Container for the parameters to the CreateCluster operation. Creates an empty cluster. Each cluster supports five nodes. You use the CreateJob action separately to create the jobs for each of these nodes. The cluster does not ship until these five node jobs have been created.

member.summary:

Specifies the service or services on the Snow Family device that your transferred data will be exported from or imported into. AWS Snow Family supports Amazon S3 and NFS (Network File System).

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.CreateClusterRequest.RemoteManagement
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RemoteManagement.
Allows you to securely operate and manage Snow devices in a cluster remotely from outside of your internal network. When set to INSTALLED_AUTOSTART, remote management will automatically be available when the device arrives at your location. Otherwise, you need to use the Snowball Client to manage the device.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.CreateClusterRequest.Resources
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Resources.
The resources associated with the cluster job. These resources include Amazon S3 buckets and optional AWS Lambda functions written in the Python language.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.CreateClusterRequest.RoleARN
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RoleARN.
The RoleARN that you want to associate with this cluster. RoleArn values are created by using the CreateRole API action in AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM).

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.CreateClusterRequest.ShippingOption
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ShippingOption.
The shipping speed for each node in this cluster. This speed doesn't dictate how soon you'll get each Snowball Edge device, rather it represents how quickly each device moves to its destination while in transit. Regional shipping speeds are as follows:
In Australia, you have access to express shipping. Typically, Snow devices shipped express are delivered in about a day.
In the European Union (EU), you have access to express shipping. Typically, Snow devices shipped express are delivered in about a day. In addition, most countries in the EU have access to standard shipping, which typically takes less than a week, one way.
In India, Snow devices are delivered in one to seven days.
In the United States of America (US), you have access to one-day shipping and two-day shipping.

In India, Snow devices are delivered in one to seven days.
In the US, you have access to one-day shipping and two-day shipping.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.CreateClusterRequest.SnowballType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SnowballType.
The type of AWS Snow Family device to use for this cluster.
For cluster jobs, AWS Snow Family currently supports only the EDGE device type.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.CreateJobRequest.RemoteManagement
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RemoteManagement.
Allows you to securely operate and manage Snowcone devices remotely from outside of your internal network. When set to INSTALLED_AUTOSTART, remote management will automatically be available when the device arrives at your location. Otherwise, you need to use the Snowball Client to manage the device.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.CreateJobRequest.Resources
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Resources.
Defines the Amazon S3 buckets associated with this job.
With IMPORT jobs, you specify the bucket or buckets that your transferred data will be imported into.
With EXPORT jobs, you specify the bucket or buckets that your transferred data will be exported from. Optionally, you can also specify a KeyRange value. If you choose to export a range, you define the length of the range by providing either an inclusive BeginMarker value, an inclusive EndMarker value, or both. Ranges are UTF-8 binary sorted.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.CreateJobRequest.ShippingOption
member.summary:

The shipping speed for this job. This speed doesn't dictate how soon you'll get the Snow device, rather it represents how quickly the Snow device moves to its destination while in transit. Regional shipping speeds are as follows:
In Australia, you have access to express shipping. Typically, Snow devices shipped express are delivered in about a day.
In the European Union (EU), you have access to express shipping. Typically, Snow devices shipped express are delivered in about a day. In addition, most countries in the EU have access to standard shipping, which typically takes less than a week, one way.
In India, Snow devices are delivered in one to seven days.
In the US, you have access to one-day shipping and two-day shipping.

The long-term usage is a 1-year or 3-year long-term pricing type for the device. You are billed upfront, and AWS provides discounts for long-term pricing.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.CreateLongTermPricingRequest.IsLongTermPricingAutoRenew
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property IsLongTermPricingAutoRenew.
Specifies whether the current long-term pricing type for the device should be renewed.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.CreateLongTermPricingRequest.LongTermPricingType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property LongTermPricingType.
The type of long-term pricing option you want for the device, either 1-year or 3-year long-term pricing.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.CreateLongTermPricingRequest.SnowballType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SnowballType.
The type of AWS Snow Family device to use for the long-term pricing job.

The shipping speed for a particular job. This speed doesn't dictate how soon the device is returned to AWS. This speed represents how quickly it moves to its destination while in transit. Regional shipping speeds are as follows:

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.DataTransfer.ObjectsTransferred
member.summary:

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.DataTransfer.TotalBytes
member.summary:

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.DataTransfer.TotalObjects

member.name: T:Amazon.Snowball.Model.GetJobManifestRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the GetJobManifest operation. Returns a link to an Amazon S3 presigned URL for the manifest file associated with the specified JobId value. You can access the manifest file for up to 60 minutes after this request has been made. To access the manifest file after 60 minutes have passed, you'll have to make another call to the GetJobManifest action.
The manifest is an encrypted file that you can download after your job enters the WithCustomer status. The manifest is decrypted by using the UnlockCode code value, when you pass both values to the Snow device through the Snowball client when the client is started for the first time.
As a best practice, we recommend that you don't save a copy of an UnlockCode value in the same location as the manifest file for that job. Saving these separately helps prevent unauthorized parties from gaining access to the Snow device associated with that job.
The credentials of a given job, including its manifest file and unlock code, expire 360 days after the job is created.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.GetJobManifestRequest.JobId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property JobId.
The ID for a job that you want to get the manifest file for, for example JID123e4567-e89b-12d3-a456-426655440000.

member.name: T:Amazon.Snowball.Model.GetJobManifestResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the GetJobManifest operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.GetJobManifestResponse.ManifestURI
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ManifestURI.
The Amazon S3 presigned URL for the manifest file associated with the specified JobId value.

member.name: T:Amazon.Snowball.Model.GetJobUnlockCodeRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the GetJobUnlockCode operation. Returns the UnlockCode code value for the specified job. A particular UnlockCode value can be accessed for up to 360 days after the associated job has been created.
The UnlockCode value is a 29-character code with 25 alphanumeric characters and 4 hyphens. This code is used to decrypt the manifest file when it is passed along with the manifest to the Snow device through the Snowball client when the client is started for the first time.
As a best practice, we recommend that you don't save a copy of the UnlockCode in the same location as the manifest file for that job. Saving these separately helps prevent unauthorized parties from gaining access to the Snow device associated with that job.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.GetJobUnlockCodeRequest.JobId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property JobId.
The ID for the job that you want to get the UnlockCode value for, for example JID123e4567-e89b-12d3-a456-426655440000.

member.name: T:Amazon.Snowball.Model.GetJobUnlockCodeResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the GetJobUnlockCode operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.GetJobUnlockCodeResponse.UnlockCode
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property UnlockCode.
The UnlockCode value for the specified job. The UnlockCode value can be accessed for up to 360 days after the job has been created.

member.name: T:Amazon.Snowball.Model.GetSnowballUsageRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the GetSnowballUsage operation. Returns information about the Snow Family service limit for your account, and also the number of Snow devices your account has in use.
The default service limit for the number of Snow devices that you can have at one time is 1. If you want to increase your service limit, contact AWS Support.

member.name: T:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobListEntry
member.summary: Each JobListEntry object contains a job's state, a job's ID, and a value that indicates whether the job is a job part, in the case of an export job.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobListEntry.CreationDate
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property CreationDate.
The creation date for this job.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobListEntry.Description
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Description.
The optional description of this specific job, for example Important Photos 2016-08-11.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobListEntry.IsMaster
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property IsMaster.
A value that indicates that this job is a main job. A main job represents a successful request to create an export job. Main jobs aren't associated with any Snowballs. Instead, each main job will have at least one job part, and each job part is associated with a Snowball. It might take some time before the job parts associated with a particular main job are listed, because they are created after the main job is created.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobListEntry.JobId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property JobId.
The automatically generated ID for a job, for example JID123e4567-e89b-12d3-a456-426655440000.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobListEntry.JobState
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property JobState.
The current state of this job.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobListEntry.JobType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property JobType.
The type of job.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobListEntry.SnowballType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SnowballType.
The type of device used with this job.

member.name: T:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobLogs
member.summary:
Contains job logs. Whenever a Snow device is used to import data into or export data out of Amazon S3, you'll have the option of downloading a PDF job report. Job logs are returned as a part of the response syntax of the DescribeJob action in the JobMetadata data type. The job logs can be accessed for up to 60 minutes after this request has been made. To access any of the job logs after 60 minutes have passed, you'll have to make another call to the DescribeJob action.
For import jobs, the PDF job report becomes available at the end of the import process. For export jobs, your job report typically becomes available while the Snow device for your job part is being delivered to you.
The job report provides you insight into the state of your Amazon S3 data transfer. The report includes details about your job or job part for your records.
For deeper visibility into the status of your transferred objects, you can look at the two associated logs: a success log and a failure log. The logs are saved in comma-separated value (CSV) format, and the name of each log includes the ID of the job or job part that the log describes.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobLogs.JobCompletionReportURI
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property JobCompletionReportURI.
A link to an Amazon S3 presigned URL where the job completion report is located.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobLogs.JobFailureLogURI
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property JobFailureLogURI.
A link to an Amazon S3 presigned URL where the job failure log is located.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobLogs.JobSuccessLogURI
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property JobSuccessLogURI.
A link to an Amazon S3 presigned URL where the job success log is located.

member.name: T:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobMetadata
member.summary: Contains information about a specific job including shipping information, job status, and other important metadata. This information is returned as a part of the response syntax of the DescribeJob action.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobMetadata.AddressId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property AddressId.
The ID for the address that you want the Snow device shipped to.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobMetadata.ClusterId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ClusterId.
The 39-character ID for the cluster, for example CID123e4567-e89b-12d3-a456-426655440000.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobMetadata.CreationDate
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property CreationDate.
The creation date for this job.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobMetadata.DataTransferProgress
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property DataTransferProgress.
A value that defines the real-time status of a Snow device's data transfer while the device is at AWS. This data is only available while a job has a JobState value of InProgress, for both import and export jobs.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobMetadata.Description
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Description.
The description of the job, provided at job creation.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobMetadata.DeviceConfiguration
member.summary: Gets and sets the property DeviceConfiguration.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobMetadata.ForwardingAddressId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ForwardingAddressId.
The ID of the address that you want a job shipped to, after it will be shipped to its primary address. This field is not supported in most regions.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobMetadata.JobId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property JobId.
The automatically generated ID for a job, for example JID123e4567-e89b-12d3-a456-426655440000.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobMetadata.JobLogInfo
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property JobLogInfo.
Links to Amazon S3 presigned URLs for the job report and logs. For import jobs, the PDF job report becomes available at the end of the import process. For export jobs, your job report typically becomes available while the Snow device for your job part is being delivered to you.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobMetadata.JobState
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property JobState.
The current status of the jobs.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobMetadata.JobType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property JobType.
The type of job.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobMetadata.KmsKeyARN
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property KmsKeyARN.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) key associated with this job. This ARN was created using the CreateKey API action in AWS KMS.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobMetadata.LongTermPricingId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property LongTermPricingId.
The ID of the long-term pricing type for the device.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobMetadata.Notification
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Notification.
The Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) notification settings associated with a specific job. The Notification object is returned as a part of the response syntax of the DescribeJob action in the JobMetadata data type.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobMetadata.OnDeviceServiceConfiguration
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property OnDeviceServiceConfiguration.
Represents metadata and configuration settings for services on an AWS Snow Family device.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobMetadata.RemoteManagement
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RemoteManagement.
Allows you to securely operate and manage Snowcone devices remotely from outside of your internal network. When set to INSTALLED_AUTOSTART, remote management will automatically be available when the device arrives at your location. Otherwise, you need to use the Snowball Client to manage the device.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobMetadata.Resources
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Resources.
An array of S3Resource objects. Each S3Resource object represents an Amazon S3 bucket that your transferred data will be exported from or imported into.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobMetadata.RoleARN
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RoleARN.
The role ARN associated with this job. This ARN was created using the CreateRole API action in AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM).

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobMetadata.ShippingDetails
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ShippingDetails.
A job's shipping information, including inbound and outbound tracking numbers and shipping speed options.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.JobMetadata.SnowballCapacityPreference
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SnowballCapacityPreference.
The Snow device capacity preference for this job, specified at job creation. In US regions, you can choose between 50 TB and 80 TB Snowballs. All other regions use 80 TB capacity Snowballs.

member.summary:
The Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) notification settings associated with a specific job. The Notification object is returned as a part of the response syntax of the DescribeJob action in the JobMetadata data type.
When the notification settings are defined during job creation, you can choose to notify based on a specific set of job states using the JobStatesToNotify array of strings, or you can specify that you want to have Amazon SNS notifications sent out for all job states with NotifyAll set to true.

The new SNS TopicArn that you want to associate with this job. You can create Amazon Resource Names (ARNs) for topics by using the CreateTopic Amazon SNS API action.
You can subscribe email addresses to an Amazon SNS topic through the AWS Management Console, or by using the Subscribe Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) API action.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.Shipment.TrackingNumber
member.summary:

The tracking number for this job. Using this tracking number with your region's carrier's website, you can track a Snow device as the carrier transports it.
For India, the carrier is Amazon Logistics. For all other regions, UPS is the carrier.

member.summary:

member.summary:

The Status and TrackingNumber values for a Snow device being delivered to the address that you specified for a particular job.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.ShippingDetails.ShippingOption
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ShippingOption.
The shipping speed for a particular job. This speed doesn't dictate how soon you'll get the Snow device from the job's creation date. This speed represents how quickly it moves to its destination while in transit. Regional shipping speeds are as follows:
In Australia, you have access to express shipping. Typically, Snow devices shipped express are delivered in about a day.
In the European Union (EU), you have access to express shipping. Typically, Snow devices shipped express are delivered in about a day. In addition, most countries in the EU have access to standard shipping, which typically takes less than a week, one way.
In India, Snow devices are delivered in one to seven days.
In the United States of America (US), you have access to one-day shipping and two-day shipping.

The updated description of this job's JobMetadata object.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.UpdateJobRequest.ForwardingAddressId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ForwardingAddressId.
The updated ID for the forwarding address for a job. This field is not supported in most regions.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.UpdateJobRequest.JobId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property JobId.
The job ID of the job that you want to update, for example JID123e4567-e89b-12d3-a456-426655440000.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.UpdateJobRequest.Notification
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Notification.
The new or updated Notification object.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.UpdateJobRequest.OnDeviceServiceConfiguration
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property OnDeviceServiceConfiguration.
Specifies the service or services on the Snow Family device that your transferred data will be exported from or imported into. AWS Snow Family supports Amazon S3 and NFS (Network File System).

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.UpdateJobRequest.Resources
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Resources.
The updated JobResource object, or the updated JobResource object.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.UpdateJobRequest.RoleARN
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RoleARN.
The new role Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that you want to associate with this job. To create a role ARN, use the CreateRoleAWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) API action.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.UpdateJobRequest.ShippingOption
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ShippingOption.
The updated shipping option value of this job's ShippingDetails object.

member.name: P:Amazon.Snowball.Model.UpdateJobRequest.SnowballCapacityPreference
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SnowballCapacityPreference.
The updated SnowballCapacityPreference of this job's JobMetadata object. The 50 TB Snowballs are only available in the US regions.
For more information, see "https://docs.aws.amazon.com/snowball/latest/snowcone-guide/snow-device-types.html" (Snow Family Devices and Capacity) in the Snowcone User Guide or "https://docs.aws.amazon.com/snowball/latest/developer-guide/snow-device-types.html" (Snow Family Devices and Capacity) in the Snowcone User Guide.

member.name: T:Amazon.Snowball.AmazonSnowballClient
member.summary:
Implementation for accessing Snowball
AWS Snow Family is a petabyte-scale data transport solution that uses secure devices to transfer large amounts of data between your on-premises data centers and Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3). The Snow commands described here provide access to the same functionality that is available in the AWS Snow Family Management Console, which enables you to create and manage jobs for a Snow device. To transfer data locally with a Snow device, you'll need to use the Snowball Edge client or the Amazon S3 API Interface for Snowball or AWS OpsHub for Snow Family. For more information, see the User Guide.

member.name: M:Amazon.Snowball.AmazonSnowballClient.#ctor
member.summary:
Constructs AmazonSnowballClient with the credentials loaded from the application's default configuration, and if unsuccessful from the Instance Profile service on an EC2 instance.
Example App.config with credentials set.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="AWSProfileName" value="AWS Default"/> </appSettings> </configuration>

member.name: M:Amazon.Snowball.AmazonSnowballClient.GetJobManifest(Amazon.Snowball.Model.GetJobManifestRequest)
member.summary:
Returns a link to an Amazon S3 presigned URL for the manifest file associated with the specified JobId value. You can access the manifest file for up to 60 minutes after this request has been made. To access the manifest file after 60 minutes have passed, you'll have to make another call to the GetJobManifest action.
The manifest is an encrypted file that you can download after your job enters the WithCustomer status. The manifest is decrypted by using the UnlockCode code value, when you pass both values to the Snow device through the Snowball client when the client is started for the first time.
As a best practice, we recommend that you don't save a copy of an UnlockCode value in the same location as the manifest file for that job. Saving these separately helps prevent unauthorized parties from gaining access to the Snow device associated with that job.
The credentials of a given job, including its manifest file and unlock code, expire 360 days after the job is created.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the GetJobManifest service method.
member.returns: The response from the GetJobManifest service method, as returned by Snowball.
member.exception: The action can't be performed because the job's current state doesn't allow that action to be performed.
The specified resource can't be found. Check the information you provided in your last request, and try again.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for GetJobManifest Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.Snowball.AmazonSnowballClient.GetJobUnlockCode(Amazon.Snowball.Model.GetJobUnlockCodeRequest)
member.summary:
Returns the UnlockCode code value for the specified job. A particular UnlockCode value can be accessed for up to 360 days after the associated job has been created.
The UnlockCode value is a 29-character code with 25 alphanumeric characters and 4 hyphens. This code is used to decrypt the manifest file when it is passed along with the manifest to the Snow device through the Snowball client when the client is started for the first time.
As a best practice, we recommend that you don't save a copy of the UnlockCode in the same location as the manifest file for that job. Saving these separately helps prevent unauthorized parties from gaining access to the Snow device associated with that job.

member.name: T:Amazon.Snowball.IAmazonSnowball
member.summary:
Interface for accessing Snowball
AWS Snow Family is a petabyte-scale data transport solution that uses secure devices to transfer large amounts of data between your on-premises data centers and Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3). The Snow commands described here provide access to the same functionality that is available in the AWS Snow Family Management Console, which enables you to create and manage jobs for a Snow device. To transfer data locally with a Snow device, you'll need to use the Snowball Edge client or the Amazon S3 API Interface for Snowball or AWS OpsHub for Snow Family. For more information, see the User Guide.

member.name: M:Amazon.Snowball.IAmazonSnowball.GetJobManifest(Amazon.Snowball.Model.GetJobManifestRequest)
member.summary:
Returns a link to an Amazon S3 presigned URL for the manifest file associated with the specified JobId value. You can access the manifest file for up to 60 minutes after this request has been made. To access the manifest file after 60 minutes have passed, you'll have to make another call to the GetJobManifest action.
The manifest is an encrypted file that you can download after your job enters the WithCustomer status. The manifest is decrypted by using the UnlockCode code value, when you pass both values to the Snow device through the Snowball client when the client is started for the first time.
As a best practice, we recommend that you don't save a copy of an UnlockCode value in the same location as the manifest file for that job. Saving these separately helps prevent unauthorized parties from gaining access to the Snow device associated with that job.
The credentials of a given job, including its manifest file and unlock code, expire 360 days after the job is created.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the GetJobManifest service method.
member.returns: The response from the GetJobManifest service method, as returned by Snowball.
member.exception: The action can't be performed because the job's current state doesn't allow that action to be performed.
The specified resource can't be found. Check the information you provided in your last request, and try again.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for GetJobManifest Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.Snowball.IAmazonSnowball.GetJobUnlockCode(Amazon.Snowball.Model.GetJobUnlockCodeRequest)
member.summary:
Returns the UnlockCode code value for the specified job. A particular UnlockCode value can be accessed for up to 360 days after the associated job has been created.
The UnlockCode value is a 29-character code with 25 alphanumeric characters and 4 hyphens. This code is used to decrypt the manifest file when it is passed along with the manifest to the Snow device through the Snowball client when the client is started for the first time.
As a best practice, we recommend that you don't save a copy of the UnlockCode in the same location as the manifest file for that job. Saving these separately helps prevent unauthorized parties from gaining access to the Snow device associated with that job.

member.returns: The response from the GetJobUnlockCode service method, as returned by Snowball.

member.name: M:Amazon.Snowball.IAmazonSnowball.GetSnowballUsage(Amazon.Snowball.Model.GetSnowballUsageRequest)
member.summary:
Returns information about the Snow Family service limit for your account, and also the number of Snow devices your account has in use.
The default service limit for the number of Snow devices that you can have at one time is 1. If you want to increase your service limit, contact AWS Support.
